body: I'm going to play the voice of unpopular opinion: do we really need these in RA?  What gameplay gap in the RA mod do they fill?  It took quite some time to recover from the "add ALL the things (and deal with the balance implications later)" phase of the RA mod.

They aren't buildable. Not just because they have no icon, but also because you don't need them in multiplayer. I plan to use this in a Lua port of @ScottNZ's spy co-op mission where you have to get past a checkpoint. https://github.com/Mailaender/OpenRA/tree/infiltration-mission

It may be better to include them as map specific rules.  The last time we added a new actor type for a planned mission was the zombie, and that instead sat around for years without strong justification for keeping it.
Give it time. Last Sunday someone finally delivered: http://resource.openra.net/maps/8514/

I consider two years and 6 months (plus a cameo in the shellmap appearance once a year that could be replaced by ants) to be enough time by more than an order of magnitude.  They could quite easily live as map-specific rules in that map.

Why do you come up with removing these just when we finished our job and why the derailing of this pull request with zombie sprite comparisons. This isn't adding a new unit, but more like a decorational element. If we don't set up the rules in the base mod, it will stay invisible in the map editor with zero discoverability.

I have a long history of objecting to adding new third-party content that doesn't have a clear use-case.
Setting these up as a hidden prop is IMO much less useful than integrating them properly with the game (after making sure that they have a place in the balance).

I bring up the zombie sprite comparisons because I believe that those were added under the same "I have a specific mission in mind that will use this, but they won't be available anywhere else" logic.
~~Added the props to a map so we get a showcase. Doubt it impacts balancing.~~

The more map props, the merrier. Technically they aren't hidden this way anyway since the map editor shows them and not every mapper is a YAML modder as well to enable them themselves.

The zombie is clearly a mission unit, due to having an active role. Map props like, say Nooze's lighthouse or gates are a complete different thingy.

~~yeah , no ... we dont need this in RA1 ... the next release will feature proper wall-defending (as they are finally fixed) ... so this will change the gameplay allready (most likely)~~
Edit: i didnt read correct

i dont think we need our most played mod to be the lab-monkey for every new feature (even though this is open-source we do have to maintain a stock of regular players)
and i know its a good thing that we can finally make those gates ... but theres no reason to add them to RA ... (other then for showing off) 

this and the fact that gates were actually introduced in Tiberian Sun ... i think we should leave the "surprise" for this feature on our Tiberian Sun-mod (this is just my own personal oppinion) ... 
*what i mean by that is ... when i play TS ... i would actuallly like to play something else other then RA/TD or D2K ... features like the gates ... make Tiberian Sun "different" and "new" for me 

:-1:
As a compromise, could we add these as map-specific assets/rules to Fort Lonestar?

> As a compromise, could we add these as map-specific assets/rules to Fort Lonestar?

thats okay for me
Note that ^ is assuming that it wouldn't hurt the gameplay of Lonestar.  Ping @abcdefg30.

Sorry, but I don't think that this would be a good idea, as gates would delay your units from moving out of the base and instead of adding further protection, make you more vulnerable to flame artillery.

We can of course try it though, just ping me on IRC if you want a testgame.

Anyway, I think the original idea was to use this for an interior mission?

The original idea is to keep this in the map editor available for everyone. It will probably be used in single-player missions as a decorational gimmick. This won't break multiplayer games as it isn't available there and this doesn't need to be added to each map individually. The whole discussion sparked here is mostly uninformed nonsense.

I see no reason to blanket-add this feature to RA.
Mappers are capable of implementing it themselves if they really want it, and say after some months we notice most maps do have them perhaps we could revisit the discussion with actual figures rather than "probably/maybe".

@Micr0Bit made an excellent point about gates being a special TS-only feature.

Just because you don't agree with the discussion doesn't mean it is uninformed nonsense.

One should not expect mappers to understand the underlying game for additional assets to be utilized. That's a modder's work.

A mapper won't add something to his/her map without the knowledge of said thing exists which is why it should be added to the map editor and thereby the game first. Your counterargument is stupid and relies on the expectation that all mappers are modders.

@GraionDilach : the thing though is ... stuff that is easy available for "mappers" also gets heavily used in maps ... zombies and ants as best example (biolab , right?)

imagine all the mappers combined together as a big child ... the devs give them a couple of red and blue bricks ... now the child builds various structures with those bricks ... 

what you can do now is ... give the child a special yellow brick , which it can use after a bit of effort to set "accents" on his buildings ...

or 

just give him the yellow brick without it having any effort , and then have hundreds of stuctures , everything contains a mix of red-blue-yellow bricks ... 
or even worse ... the chance of having (several) buildings containing "only" yellow bricks will be increased significantly

What is the difference between gates and say, lighthouse or windmill? Ah yeah, nothing.

Both are just map props, yet one gets added without any argument/usecase and one is booed to hell. That's everything I think about this.
isnt't the gate a "state-changing" feature which could potentially affect the game-outcome ?

The lighthouse and windmill are generic map props that could be reasonably expected to be used across many maps.  Gates are very specific, and nobody has yet presented even one specific usecase for them in RA maps (except for Lonestar, which was shot down for a valid reason).

> The lighthouse and windmill are generic map props that could be reasonably expected to be used across many maps. Gates are very specific, and nobody has yet presented even one specific usecase for them in RA maps (except for Lonestar, which was shot down for a valid reason).

I should say i disagree to you. Gates are also usable in most maps, in my case they are more usable because almost all of my maps includes an army base. Props are props, using them is left to mapper if we add them mappers can find a usage don't worry about it.

> nobody has yet presented even one specific usecase for them in RA maps

Like I wrote last month https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/10613#issuecomment-175245358 I actually had a specific use case in mind. As a workaround @ScottNZ built a barrier with sand bags and infantry moving aside at that time.

But if getting even such simple dependencies merged, I doubt I will want to go through the pain of contributing a complex Lua scripted remake here. The `CHANGES REQUESTED` button or derail a pull request with FUD have become an instrument to enforce a very strict way how things have to be done, which limits the ideas and creative freedom of individual contributors.

Everybody seems to have an opinion on this, but I expect that very few people have actually downloaded this branch, tried it out and gave some hints on how to improve it, which is the only thing I ask for when submitting something for review. I don't care for meta discussions about how functional a prop can be and how possibly game-breaking or irrelevant gates were in the TS. Please leave that to the chat room or the discussion forums.

> Everybody seems to have an opinion on this, but I expect that very few people have actually downloaded this branch, tried it out and gave some hints on how to improve it, which is the only thing I ask for when submitting something for review. I don't care for meta discussions about how functional a prop can be and how possibly game-breaking or irrelevant gates were in the TS. Please leave that to the chat room or the discussion forums.

The primary purpose of a PR is to evaluate a set of changes for inclusion.  The very first point that needs to be established is "do we want this": discussion about how the feature integrates with the rest of the project is _essential_ for this.  Most technical issues with a feature can be fixed if the feature is wanted, but I don't see much point spending time commenting on technical issues if it doesn't pass the initial smell test.

I find it difficult to read the dismissal of the integration discussion as anything other than "if it works then you should merge it â€“ I don't care how this affects the game, merge it now and _you_ can sort out the details later".
My point is: the sprites are already included https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/tree/bleed/mods/ra/bits and shipped so that decision was made 4 years ago by @chrisforbes et al.
We had enough talking already. You need to come to a conclusion now. `rm -r mods/ra/gate*.shp` and upload a prefab map to http://resource.openra.net or get this merged.

I've made my opinion clear on why I think this is a bad idea, but I also don't think gates are a big enough deal to override the review process and veto the pr.  My biggest issue here has been with attitude.  If the other reviewers want gates then you'll still need to fix the FactionImages issue (I even gave some hints on how to improve it!) before merging.
@Micr0Bit: if they would be buildable by the player, then yes. However, this PR ain't make them as such, so yeah, they are still merely map props.

My two cents, since I see I haven't yet commented on this:
- I don't see why RA needs gates.
- Since we're talking about adding a map prop only (like any tree or rock), the drama over this is unnecessary. If you wanted to add them as buildable structures, then there would need to be a serious gameplay discussion.

I usually prefer to stick to the "authors need to justify why the PR needs to be merged" viewpoint, but with all the arguing this is caused (for a map prop!) I'd be OK if we compromised on taking them as nothing more than unbuildable, uncontrollable map props.

> you'll still need to fix the FactionImages issue (I even gave some hints on how to improve it!) before merging.

I used the same hack as you did for Dune 2000 now by defaulting to a hard-coded image https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/bleed/mods/d2k/rules/structures.yaml#L79
